objectives: Understand the three degrees of comparison for adjectives: Positive, Comparative, and Superlative
Learn the rules for forming comparative and superlative degrees for regular adjectives
Memorize the forms for common irregular adjectives
Use degrees of comparison correctly to compare people, places, and things in sentences

sections.text: Degrees of comparison are used with adjectives to compare one person or thing with another. There are three degrees of comparison: the Positive, the Comparative, and the Superlative. Each one serves a different purpose in making a comparison.

examples.label: Positive Degree
examples.value: This is used to describe a quality of one person or thing without comparing it to another. It is the base form of the adjective. Ex: The mango is sweet.

examples.label: Comparative Degree
examples.value: This is used to compare two people or things. It shows which one has more of a quality. Ex: This mango is sweeter than that one.

examples.label: Superlative Degree
examples.value: This is used to compare three or more people or things. It shows which one has the highest degree of the quality. Ex: This is the sweetest mango in the basket.

examples.label: Example: 'tall'
examples.value: Ram is a tall boy. (Positive) | Shyam is taller than Ram. (Comparative) | Mohan is the tallest boy in the class. (Superlative)

examples.label: Example: 'big'
examples.value: My house is big. (Positive) | Your house is bigger than mine. (Comparative) | His house is the biggest in the village. (Superlative)

examples.label: Example: 'beautiful'
examples.value: The flower is beautiful. (Positive) | The rose is more beautiful than the jasmine. (Comparative) | The lotus is the most beautiful flower in the pond. (Superlative)

examples.label: Example: 'cold'
examples.value: The water is cold. (Positive) | The water in the well is colder than the water in the river. (Comparative) | The ice is the coldest thing in the house. (Superlative)

examples.label: Example: 'fast'
examples.value: The bullock cart is fast. (Positive) | The horse is faster than the bullock cart. (Comparative) | The train is the fastest vehicle. (Superlative)

examples.label: Example: 'interesting'
examples.value: This book is interesting. (Positive) | That movie is more interesting than this book. (Comparative) | The story my grandfather told was the most interesting of all. (Superlative)

sections.text: Most adjectives are regular and follow simple rules to form their comparative and superlative degrees. The rule depends on the length of the adjective (the number of syllables).

examples.label: One-Syllable Adjectives (Add -er, -est)
examples.value: For short adjectives, we usually add '-er' for the comparative and '-est' for the superlative. (e.g., long -> longer -> longest)

examples.label: Example: 'high'
examples.value: The hill is high. The mountain is higher than the hill. Mount Everest is the highest mountain.

examples.label: Example: 'strong'
examples.value: He is a strong man. His brother is stronger than him. The wrestler is the strongest man in the competition.

examples.label: Example: 'small'
examples.value: My village is small. Your village is smaller than mine. His village is the smallest in the district.

examples.label: Example: 'cold'
examples.value: Today is a cold day. Yesterday was colder than today. January is the coldest month of the year.

examples.label: Two-Syllable Adjectives ending in -y (Change y to i, add -er, -est)
examples.value: For adjectives like 'happy', we change the 'y' to 'i' before adding '-er' and '-est'. (e.g., happy -> happier -> happiest)

examples.label: Example: 'easy'
examples.value: This question is easy. The second question is easier than the first. The last question is the easiest of all.

examples.label: Example: 'heavy'
examples.value: This bag is heavy. That bag is heavier than this one. The sack of rice is the heaviest of all.

examples.label: Example: 'pretty'
examples.value: She has a pretty dress. Her sister's dress is prettier. The bride had the prettiest dress at the wedding.

examples.label: Example: 'lazy'
examples.value: The boy is lazy. His friend is lazier than him. He is the laziest boy in the entire school.

examples.label: Long Adjectives (Use 'more' and 'most')
examples.value: For longer adjectives (usually with two or more syllables), we use 'more' for the comparative and 'most' for the superlative before the adjective. (e.g., beautiful -> more beautiful -> most beautiful)

examples.label: Example: 'important'
examples.value: Education is important. Health is more important than wealth. Honesty is the most important quality.

examples.label: Example: 'difficult'
examples.value: This sum is difficult. The next sum is more difficult than this one. The last sum is the most difficult in the book.

examples.label: Example: 'expensive'
examples.value: This saree is expensive. The silk saree is more expensive than the cotton one. The wedding saree was the most expensive of all.

examples.label: Example: 'courageous'
examples.value: The soldier was courageous. His leader was more courageous. The king was the most courageous of them all.

sections.text: When adding '-er' or '-est', sometimes the spelling of the base adjective changes slightly.

table.title: Spelling Rules
rows: Adjectives ending in '-e'. Just add '-r' and '-st'.
Adjectives ending in '-e'. Just add '-r' and '-st'.
Adjectives ending in a consonant + 'y'. Change 'y' to 'i'.
Adjectives ending in a consonant + 'y'. Change 'y' to 'i'.
Adjectives ending in a single vowel + a single consonant. Double the final consonant.
Adjectives ending in a single vowel + a single consonant. Double the final consonant.
Adjectives ending in a single vowel + a single consonant. Double the final consonant.

sections.text: Some common adjectives do not follow any of the rules. Their comparative and superlative forms are completely different and must be memorized.

examples.label: Good -> Better -> Best
examples.value: This is a good story. Your story is better than mine. This is the best story in the book.

examples.label: Good -> Better -> Best (Sentence 2)
examples.value: He is a good farmer. His neighbour is a better farmer. Mr. Sharma is the best farmer in our village.

examples.label: Bad -> Worse -> Worst
examples.value: The weather was bad yesterday. Today, the weather is worse. This is the worst storm of the year.

examples.label: Bad -> Worse -> Worst (Sentence 2)
examples.value: His handwriting is bad. My handwriting is worse than his. Her handwriting is the worst in the class.

examples.label: Little -> Less -> Least
examples.value: I have little water. You have less water than me. He has the least water of all.

examples.label: Little -> Less -> Least (Sentence 2)
examples.value: There is little hope of rain. There is less hope now than yesterday. This is the least of my worries.

examples.label: Much / Many -> More -> Most
examples.value: He has many books. She has more books than him. The library has the most books.

examples.label: Much / Many -> More -> Most (Sentence 2)
examples.value: This work needs much effort. The next task will need more effort. The final project needs the most effort.

examples.label: Far -> Farther / Further -> Farthest / Furthest
examples.value: My village is far. The city is farther than my village. The capital is the farthest city from here.

examples.label: Far -> Farther / Further -> Farthest / Furthest (Sentence 2)
examples.value: We need to discuss this further. (further for metaphorical distance) | The farthest I have ever traveled is to Delhi.

sections.text: Here are some important tips to remember when using degrees of comparison in your sentences.
usage_examples: Tip 1: Use 'than' with the Comparative Degree. When you compare two things, the word 'than' is used after the comparative adjective. Example: 'He is stronger than his brother.'
Tip 2: Use 'the' before the Superlative Degree. The superlative degree is almost always preceded by the article 'the'. Example: 'She is the smartest student in the class.'

Tip 3: Never use a double comparative or superlative. Do not say 'more taller' or 'most tallest'. This is a common mistake. Just say 'taller' and 'tallest'. Similarly, don't say 'more better'; 'better' is already a comparative.

Tip 4: Counting syllables can help. A syllable is a unit of pronunciation having one vowel sound. 'Big' has one syllable. 'Ha-ppy' has two. 'Beau-ti-ful' has three. This helps you decide whether to use '-er/-est' or 'more/most'.
Tip 5: Practice by comparing things around you. Look at two trees and say, 'This tree is taller than that tree.' Look at all the students in your class and think, 'Who is the tallest student?'

Tip 6: Using 'Elder' and 'Eldest'. 'Elder' and 'eldest' are used only for people (usually within a family), and they cannot be followed by 'than'. 'Older' and 'oldest' can be used for both people and things. Example: 'My elder brother is a doctor.' (Correct) 'He is elder than me.' (Incorrect - use 'older than me').
